item.title: CTI Homelab Series - 1.1 Planning, Objectives, and Direction
item.description: Note This is part 1 of a two-part series on Planning, Objectives, and Direction. PIRs and collection planning will be detailed in 1.2. Resources Required: Something to take notes with. Objectives: Develop stakeholder interviews (1.1) Identify “crown jewels” (1.1) Develop and rank Priority Intelligence Requirements (PIRs) (1.2) Determine collection methods and strategies (1.2) Scenario The CEO has decided that with the changing threat landscape, it’s time to dedicate time, effort, and energy to adapting to the times and creating a digital security culture for the organization.

item.title: CTI Homelab Series - Introduction
item.description: Prologue I’m going to go out on a limb and state that Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) is one of the hardest domains within Cybersecurity to get into, let alone understand. Heck, what even is CTI anyway? How does it tie into the rest of Cybersecurity? What does it take to become a CTI Analyst? How do I become one? This blog series is intended for those who have an interest in learning more about CTI or who would like some hands-on projects to sink their teeth into to develop their skillset.

Oh, so you’ve ventured over here to know a little more about me? I’m nobody special. Another anonymous voice on the internet. One thing I can proudly say is that I’m 100% organic. No AI generated content goes here. To humor you for clicking this page, I’m a self-taught Cybersecurity professional currently working as a CTI Analyst. My hobbies include reading copius amounts of dry literature on philosophy, human psychology, cybersecurity, geopolitical affairs, and economics.
